mdc-u-ts-5"><div class="mck-u-links-inline">COVID-19 may no longer be a pandemic, but the disease likely reduced the availability of the US workforce by as much as 2.6 percent in 2022a burden on productivity that could last for years.</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 <div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Fhealthcare%20systems%20and%20services%2Four%20insights%2Fone%20billion%20days%20lost%20how%20covid%2019%20is%20hurting%20the%20us%20workforce%2Fone-billion-days-lost-how-covid-19-is-hurting-the-us-workforce.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="one-billion-days-lost-how-covid-19-is-hurting-the-us-workforce" data-layer-report-name="one-billion-days-lost-how-covid-19-is-hurting-the-us-workforce>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (7 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>COVID-19 has gradually</strong> become a part of the US landscape. Changes in official policy have indicated as much, as has the publics clear acceptance of the risks of the disease. These shifts are consistent with the <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/when-will-the-covid-19-pandemic-end">scenarios</a> that we and others have described: COVID-19 is now endemic in the United States.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="mck-c-inline-module-container SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__bgimg-wrapper__Qj4Dt mck-o-sm-left-span SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper__Dpjw2 class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body">This article is a collaborative effort by Charlie Berdan, <a href="/our-people/sarun-charumilind">Sarun Charumilind</a>, <a href="/our-people/matt-craven">Matt Craven</a>, <a href="/our-people/jessica-lamb">Jessica Lamb</a>, and <a href="/our-people/shubham-singhal">Shubham Singhal</a>, representing views from McKinseys Healthcare Systems & Services Practice.</div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>However, that does not mean that we have defeated the disease. Every day, between 250 and 400 US families lose a loved one to COVID-19.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f0923998-0466-448e-b0bd-48ec19163f08"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f0923998-0466-448e-b0bd-48ec19163f08" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Coronavirus in the US: Latest map and case count, <em>New York Times</em>, November 23December 15, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Thats roughly 2.5 to 4.0 times the average number of daily deaths from the flu in the decade preceding the pandemic.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e1aaa85b-3062-4b1d-a323-d8d41ab20253"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e1aaa85b-3062-4b1d-a323-d8d41ab20253" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Data from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) show an average of about 35,000 deaths from influenza per year in the United States from 2010 to 2020, or about 100 per day if deaths were evenly distributed across the year. See Past seasons estimated influenza disease burden, CDC, accessed November 2022.</span></span></span></a></span>  For these families (and those of the more than one million victims since 2020), COVID-19 is an unalloyed tragedy.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>Another ongoing effect of COVID-19 is less critical, and less obvious, but nevertheless substantial: <span style="line-height:110%">more than </span>two years after the lockdown, the disease continues to exert a brake on the US economy through productive workdays lost to worker illness, caregivers responsibilities for children and seniors, and compliance with isolation guidelines. And some analysts are starting to notice.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="114b1ceb-acf1-4765-930a-69bd6a4efb97"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="114b1ceb-acf1-4765-930a-69bd6a4efb97" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">See, for example, Gwynn Guilford and Lauren Weber, Covids drag on the workforce proves persistent: It sets us back, <em>Wall Street Journal</em>, November 7, 2022; Kathryn A. Edwards, Mass long-Covid disability threatens the economy, Bloomberg, December 8, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>We estimate that each case of COVID-19including both those diagnosed and those that do not make it into official statisticsleads to <span style="line-height:110%">1.0 to 1.5</span> days of productive work lost, depending on the scenario. By itself, that is not catastrophic for anyone, worker or employer. But the scale of the endemic is vast: the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation suggests that there were 315 million to 690 million COVID-19 cases in the United States in 2022. Only a small portion of these cases, however, are captured in public-health statistics.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="526fb76c-7d2f-4363-a96e-5c705148a340"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="526fb76c-7d2f-4363-a96e-5c705148a340" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">COVID-19 projections, Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation, November 23, 2022. Projections run through February 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p><span style="line-height:110%">Do the math, and 315 million to 1.05 billion worker days were likely lost to COVID-19 last year, equivalent to 1.3 million to 4.3 million workers dropping out of the workforce for the full year.</span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5d2dabce-c4c4-4291-9ff7-d67bb2cb18dd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5d2dabce-c4c4-4291-9ff7-d67bb2cb18dd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Assuming that the average full-time employee works 240 days per year.</span></span></span></a></span> At the high end, thats about double the average number of sick days taken by US workers in the decade before the pandemic. Stated differently, the cumulative impact of lost time due to COVID-19 is equivalent to a 0.8 to 2.6 percent reduction in the availability of the US workforce.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3c5c3746-b195-47b5-892e-049e1273602a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3c5c3746-b195-47b5-892e-049e1273602a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on a US labor force of 165 million, according to the US Bureau of Labor Statistics.</span></span></span></a></span>  In our view, this is a hidden loss that could help explain the persistent US worker shortage.</p>
<p>In this article we review the analysis and explain our assumptions. And while our review is confined to 2022, early epidemiological estimates suggest that US case rates will continue on a similar trajectory in early 2023<span style="line-height:110%">, particularly if new subvariants such as XBB.1.5 drive new waves of disease.</span> If that happens, then the US workforce will lose productive days at a similar rate.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1a461f84-673a-4697-b3a2-57687fcb8039"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1a461f84-673a-4697-b3a2-57687fcb8039" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Demographic trends of COVID-19 cases and deaths in the US reported to CDC, CDC, accessed on November 17, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> <span style="line-height:110%">In the m</span>eantime, severe outbreaks of influenza and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) in the United States are also wreaking havoc on workers availability.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3c775d0d-735a-4874-92b1-2bbb93d3ceca"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3c775d0d-735a-4874-92b1-2bbb93d3ceca" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">See, for example, Katherine J. Wu, The pandemic broke the flu  again, <em>Atlantic</em>, November 23, 2022. </span></span></span></a></span>  Many analysts have asked about the missing US workers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fe55b290-1566-45c0-8581-7431f567200b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fe55b290-1566-45c0-8581-7431f567200b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">See, for example, Lydia DePillis, Who are Americas missing workers?, <em>New York Times</em>, September 12, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Our answer: theyre out sick, and companies will have to adapt.</p>
<h2>How COVID-19 affects workforce productivity</h2>
<p>COVID-19 affects productivity in four ways:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Missed work due to acute illness.</em><strong><em></em> </strong>The average symptomatic person loses some productive working time because of COVID-19, and the amount of time lost varies. Some will isolate for the full recommended period, which is currently five days. (We account for these workers separately.) Others will miss work only while they feel unwellfor example, missing work for a couple of days, working at 75 percent of their usual capacity for ten days, or similar adaptations. Finally, a smaller though still meaningful number of people experience severe acute illness and miss work for a longer period.</li>
    <li><em>Productivity loss due to long COVID.</em> Long COVID is a complex and poorly understood syndrome. We recently estimated one form of its economic impact: the <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-gathering-storm-the-affordability-challenge-of-endemic-covid-19">affordability challenge</a> that it places on the nations healthcare system.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="333de6fb-d3d8-4da2-bd94-c8061a2ced33"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="333de6fb-d3d8-4da2-bd94-c8061a2ced33" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Addie Fleron, Pooja Kumar, Shubham Singhal, and Matt Wilson, <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-gathering-storm-the-affordability-challenge-of-endemic-covid-19">The gathering storm: The affordability challenge of endemic COVID-19</a>, September 21, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span>  Reduced productivity is another such challenge. A relatively large number of people experience mild to moderate medium-term symptoms, which cause a modest productivity decrease. A smaller number suffer debilitating symptoms and are unable to work for a substantial period of time.</li>
    <li><em>Missed work due to isolation based on COVID-19 protocol.</em> While compliance is far from universal, some people, irrespective of symptoms, do follow the US Centers for Disease Control and Preventions (CDCs) recommendation to isolate for at least five days after testing positive.</li>
    <li><em>Productivity loss while caregiving for a dependent family member.</em> Cases in dependent family members can also lead to workdays lost, as parents may have to care for sick children (or grandparents).</li>
</ul>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Our methodology</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>To estimate work lost</strong> in each of the four categories, we made assumptions based on our work with public-health agencies and a review of the medical literature, always keeping in mind the traditional five-day work week:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Acute illness.</em> In about two-thirds of COVID-19 cases, symptoms are present. Yet almost all symptomatic cases (98 percent) are considered mild or moderate.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="394ca6c4-23dc-46e8-8a53-6c216092fc1a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="394ca6c4-23dc-46e8-8a53-6c216092fc1a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Demographic trends of COVID-19 cases and deaths in the US reported to CDC, US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), accessed on November 17, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Recent estimates suggest that 25 to 30 percent of people infected with COVID-19 isolate for the full recommended period (currently five days) regardless of symptoms.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="402461aa-15bb-40b7-b0be-20ba2f7cc52d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="402461aa-15bb-40b7-b0be-20ba2f7cc52d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">CDC estimates 25 to 30 percent of people isolate for the full ten-day period; assumed to extend to a similar range for the five-day period. See What we know about quarantine and isolation, CDC, January 4, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Similarly, about 35 percent of people are considered able to take the time off needed to isolate for any illness, COVID-19 or otherwise.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="828df0d2-05cd-4a90-b480-723300f22c29"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="828df0d2-05cd-4a90-b480-723300f22c29" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Daniel Schneider of the Harvard Shift Project notes that of those who reported feeling ill at some point during the pandemic, 65 percent worked while they had symptoms. See Olga Khazan, The real reason Americans arent isolating, <em>Atlantic</em>, January 13, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> For about 40 percent of the isolators, working from home is not an option, and about five days of work are lost.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="74f31627-4fcf-45a1-8b29-a25be3f02ff0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="74f31627-4fcf-45a1-8b29-a25be3f02ff0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/industries/real-estate/our-insights/americans-are-embracing-flexible-work-and-they-want-more-of-it">Americans are embracing flexible workand want more of it</a>, McKinsey, June 23, 2022. Assumes the days of illness are the same as the isolation guidelines.</span></span></span></a></span> For those able to work from home, we assume that about 50 percent of their productive capacity is lost, representing some combination of working at half capacity for five days or taking around 2.5 sick days.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2e449601-8015-4126-8b78-2e044c45eeb5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2e449601-8015-4126-8b78-2e044c45eeb5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Assumes that cases of acute COVID-19 result in similar days lost as known for cases of influenza, estimated at less than one to six days per infection. See Martin Keech and Paul Beardsworth, The impact of influenza on working days lost: A review of the literature,<em> PharmacoEconomics</em>, November 2008, Volume 26, Number 11. We assume near the midpoint of this range at 2.5 days lost per case, or half capacity experienced over five days, recognizing generally milder symptoms experienced with acute COVID-19 infection.</span></span></span></a></span> Taken collectively, this group loses about 0.7 days to 1.0 day of work per case.</li>
    <li><em>Long COVID.</em> We conservatively estimate that approximately 5 percent of cases will result in long COVID symptoms that last for 50 days on average.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="167b917c-dd66-4ffc-a389-edc83b1fedc8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="167b917c-dd66-4ffc-a389-edc83b1fedc8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The medical literature is still grappling to understand the frequency, longevity, and severity of long COVID symptoms. Frequency estimations vary: the UK Office of National Statistics estimates about 4 percent as of July 2022 (Self-reported long COVID after infection with the Omicron variant in the UK, Office of National Statistics, July 18, 2022). The CDC estimates 20 percent (Lara Bull-Otterson et al., PostCOVID conditions among adult COVID-19 survivors aged 1864 and 65 YearsUnited States, March 2020November 2021, CDC, May 27, 2022). Some publications put it at 14 percent (Roy H. Perlis et al., Prevalence and correlates of long COVID symptoms among US adults, JAMA Network, October 27, 2022). Others say 6 percent (Claire E. Hastie et al., Outcomes among confirmed cases and a matched comparison group in the long-COVID in Scotland study, <em>Nature Communications</em>, October 12, 2022). We conservatively estimated that 5 percent of cases result in long COVID symptoms. The duration of long COVID is also not yet agreed on and ranges from four to 12 weeks according to several sources including the <em>BMJ</em>, NHS, and WHO. To strike a balance, we used the halfway point between the four- and 12-week estimates, or 50 days, for average duration. Severity, or the incidence and magnitude of debilitating and mild symptoms, is also not yet agreed on. Publications note debilitating symptoms occurring, such as 15 percent incidence of neurocognitive impairment (What have we learned about long COVID?, Columbia University Irving Medical Center, September 13, 2022), and 8 percent of persons experiencing challenges performing even personal care (Outcomes among confirmed cases, <em>Nature Communications</em>, October 12, 2022). We assume that 12 percent of persons experiencing long COVID may experience fully debilitating symptoms for the 50-day duration, whereas our analysis assumes around 88 percent experience only mild debilitation, or around 10 percent productivity loss for the same duration, roughly akin to the on-the-job losses experienced from the common cold (Thomas J. Bramley, Debra Lerner, and Matthew Sames, Productivity losses related to the common cold, <em>Journal of Occupational and Environmental Medicine</em>, 2002, Volume 44, Number 9).</span></span></span></a></span> Of those experiencing symptoms, we assume that 88 percent will see a loss of 10 percent of their productivity; the remaining 12 percent will experience wholly debilitating symptoms that preclude work entirely. While there is still much to learn about long COVID, we estimate the contribution of this category at 0.1 to 0.2 days of work per case.</li>
    <li><em>Isolation according to protocol. </em>About one-third of COVID-19 cases are asymptomatic. However, serial and company-mandated testing may capture up to an additional 10 percent of these cases. Assuming that about 30 percent of the population will isolate for the full five days regardless of symptoms,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="16f71069-a683-484a-a20d-a79a57cb3ba2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="16f71069-a683-484a-a20d-a79a57cb3ba2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">What we know about quarantine and isolation, CDC, January 4, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> and that about 58 percent of people can work from home,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fefb4ba0-2d6a-4e91-8368-0fcb246ada73"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fefb4ba0-2d6a-4e91-8368-0fcb246ada73" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/industries/real-estate/our-insights/americans-are-embracing-flexible-work-and-they-want-more-of-it">Americans are embracing flexible workand want more of it</a>, June 23, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> we estimate that isolation protocols cause workers to lose about 0.2 to 0.3 days of work per case.</li>
    <li><em>Caregiving.</em> For simplicity, we consider the care of only sick children under 12 (about 10 percent of all cases).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6ea248c8-db52-47c6-952e-65bbe92f6b1b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6ea248c8-db52-47c6-952e-65bbe92f6b1b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Demographic trends of COVID-19 cases and deaths in the US reported to CDC, accessed on November 17, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Recognizing the ability of many parents to work from home or find alternative caregivers, the generally milder course of COVID-19 in children, and the fact that older children will need minimal parental support, we assume that the burden of caregiving leads to 0.1 to 0.2 days of work lost by the caregiving parent, or less than 0.1 days of work lost overall.</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Across all four categories, we estimate that each case of COVID-19 in the United States currently causes workers to lose between 1.0 and 1.5 days of work (see sidebar, Our methodology, for an explanation of our assumptions). Exhibit 1 reflects three scenarios, derived from the range of our assumptions.</p>
<!-- -->
<h2>The economic impact of lost productivity</h2>
<p>Many economic analysts are puzzled by <a href="/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/somethings-coming-how-us-companies-can-build-resilience-survive-a-downturn-and-thrive-in-the-next-cycle">the conundrum in the US labor market</a>: even as the economy cools, there are still nearly twice as many job openings as there are unemployed people. It seems that one of the factors keeping workers on the sidelines is COVID-19. And on the other side of the equation, COVID-19 also seems to be a critical factor holding down productivity and hurting companies ability to keep up with demand.</p>
<p>A billion workdays lost to COVID-19 is enough to have a substantial impact on the economy. Even the midpoint scenario of roughly 600 million workdays lost represents nearly a week missed per worker on average, more than doubling the prepandemic number of sick days taken by Americans.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="70e13e34-07af-4e51-8f8e-c71f4a828a59"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="70e13e34-07af-4e51-8f8e-c71f4a828a59" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Workers reported 3.7 sick days on average from 2010 to 2019. Health status: Absence from work due to illness, Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, data extracted on November 23, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> The implied reduction of 1.5 percent in the US labor force is material at a time when unemployment stands at only 3.7 percent, and many sectors are labor constrained.</p>
<p>The impact is asymmetric across industries; those sectors whose workers are unable to be productive remotely bear a greater burden. Exhibit 2 shows our estimates of remote-working potential by sector.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/one%20billion%20days%20lost%20how%20covid%2019%20is%20hurting%20the%20us%20workforce/svgz_lostworktime_ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The impact of lost workdays is asymmetric across industries; the sectors whose workers cant be productive remotely bear the greatest burden." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/one%20billion%20days%20lost%20how%20covid%2019%20is%20hurting%20the%20us%20workforce/svgz_lostworktime_ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The impact will also likely be disproportionate across regions. Those parts of the country with higher vaccination rates among working-age populations are likely to see less work lost due to severe disease. Areas with economies that are less dependent on industries with a low potential to work remotely will also see a lighter burden.</p>
<p>Moreover, reduced productivity from COVID-19 is likely to continue into this year. Without a change in trajectory, the United States will experience hundreds of millions more COVID-19 cases in 2023, although the situation could improve if milder variants become dominant or if new preventive or therapeutic modalities reduce the average severity of cases or rates of long COVID.</p>
<p>In the meantime, workers continue to get sick and miss work. Amid the many ways that COVID-19 has slowed economies, the impact on economic productivity may be among the most enduring.</p>
<hr>
<p>While this analysis is focused on the United States, many other countries that saw a high number COVID-19 cases during 2022 are also likely to encounter a substantial effect on their workforces. Business and government leaders in these countries may want to take stock of this little-understood economic effect of COVID-19.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Charlie Berdan</strong> is a solution manager in McKinseys Chicago office, <strong><a href="/our-people/sarun-charumilind">Sarun Charumilind</a></strong> is a partner in the Philadelphia office, <strong><a href="/our-people/matt-craven">Matt Craven</a> </strong>is a partner in the Bay Area office, <strong><a href="/our-people/jessica-lamb">Jessica Lamb</a></strong> is a partner in the New Jersey office, and <strong><a href="/our-people/shubham-singhal">Shubham Singhal</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Detroit office. </p>
<hr>
<p>This article was edited by Mark Staples, an editorial director in the New York office. </p></div></div></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-screen-only"><div 2022."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-01-09T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCOVID-19 has gradually\u003c/strong\u003e become a part of the US landscape. Changes in official policy have indicated as much, as has the public\u0026rsquo;s clear acceptance of the risks of the disease. These shifts are consistent with the \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/when-will-the-covid-19-pandemic-end\"\u003escenarios\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that we and others have described: COVID-19 is now endemic in the United States.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, that does not mean that we have defeated the disease. Every day, between 250 and 400 US families lose a loved one to COVID-19.[[footnote 1]] That\u0026rsquo;s roughly 2.5 to 4.0 times the average number of daily deaths from the flu in the decade preceding the pandemic.[[footnote 2]]\u0026nbsp; For these families (and those of the more than one million victims since 2020), COVID-19 is an unalloyed tragedy.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eAnother ongoing effect of COVID-19 is less critical, and less obvious, but nevertheless substantial: \u003cspan style=\"line-height: 110%;\"\u003emore than\u0026nbsp;\u003c/span\u003etwo years after the lockdown, the disease continues to exert a brake on the US economy through productive workdays lost to worker illness, caregivers\u0026rsquo; responsibilities for children and seniors, and compliance with isolation guidelines. And some analysts are starting to notice.[[footnote 3]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe estimate that each case of COVID-19\u0026mdash;including both those diagnosed and those that do not make it into official statistics\u0026mdash;leads to\u0026nbsp;\u003cspan style=\"line-height: 110%;\"\u003e1.0 to 1.5\u003c/span\u003e days of productive work lost, depending on the scenario. By itself, that is not catastrophic for anyone, worker or employer. But the scale of the endemic is vast: the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation suggests that there were 315 million to 690 million COVID-19 cases in the United States in 2022. Only a small portion of these cases, however, are captured in public-health statistics.[[footnote 4]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"line-height: 110%;\"\u003eDo the math, and 315 million to 1.05 billion worker days were likely lost to COVID-19 last year, equivalent to 1.3 million to 4.3 million workers dropping out of the workforce for the full year.\u003c/span\u003e[[footnote 5]] At the high end, that\u0026rsquo;s about double the average number of sick days taken by US workers in the decade before the pandemic. Stated differently, the cumulative impact of lost time due to COVID-19 is equivalent to a 0.8 to 2.6 percent reduction in the availability of the US workforce.[[footnote 6]]\u0026nbsp; In our view, this is a hidden loss that could help explain the persistent US worker shortage.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this article we review the analysis and explain our assumptions. And while our review is confined to 2022, early epidemiological estimates suggest that US case rates will continue on a similar trajectory in early 2023\u003cspan style=\"line-height: 110%;\"\u003e, particularly if new subvariants such as XBB.1.5 drive new waves of disease.\u003c/span\u003e If that happens, then the US workforce will lose productive days at a similar rate.[[footnote 7]]\u0026nbsp;\u003cspan style=\"line-height: 110%;\"\u003eIn the m\u003c/span\u003eeantime, severe outbreaks of influenza and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) in the United States are also wreaking havoc on workers\u0026rsquo; availability.[[footnote 8]]\u0026nbsp; Many analysts have asked about the missing US workers.[[footnote 9]] Our answer: they\u0026rsquo;re out sick, and companies will have to adapt.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eHow COVID-19 affects workforce productivity\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCOVID-19 affects productivity in four ways:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eMissed work due to acute illness.\u003c/em\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e \u003c/strong\u003eThe average symptomatic person loses some productive working time because of COVID-19, and the amount of time lost varies. Some will isolate for the full recommended period, which is currently five days. (We account for these workers separately.) Others will miss work only while they feel unwell\u0026mdash;for example, missing work for a couple of days, working at 75 percent of their usual capacity for ten days, or similar adaptations. Finally, a smaller though still meaningful number of people experience severe acute illness and miss work for a longer period.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eProductivity loss due to long COVID.\u003c/em\u003e Long COVID is a complex and poorly understood syndrome. We recently estimated one form of its economic impact: the \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-gathering-storm-the-affordability-challenge-of-endemic-covid-19\"\u003eaffordability challenge\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that it places on the nation\u0026rsquo;s healthcare system.[[footnote 10]]\u0026nbsp; Reduced productivity is another such challenge. A relatively large number of people experience mild to moderate medium-term symptoms, which cause a modest productivity decrease. A smaller number suffer debilitating symptoms and are unable to work for a substantial period of time.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eMissed work due to isolation based on COVID-19 protocol.\u003c/em\u003e While compliance is far from universal, some people, irrespective of symptoms, do follow the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\u0026rsquo;s (CDC\u0026rsquo;s) recommendation to isolate for at least five days after testing positive.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eProductivity loss while caregiving for a dependent family member.\u003c/em\u003e Cases in dependent family members can also lead to workdays lost, as parents may have to care for sick children (or grandparents).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[sidebar 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eAcross all four categories, we estimate that each case of COVID-19 in the United States currently causes workers to lose between 1.0 and 1.5\u0026nbsp;days of work (see sidebar, \u0026ldquo;Our methodology,\u0026rdquo; for an explanation of our assumptions). Exhibit 1 reflects three scenarios, derived from the range of our assumptions.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[ceros 1]]\n\u003ch2\u003eThe economic impact of lost productivity\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMany economic analysts are puzzled by \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/somethings-coming-how-us-companies-can-build-resilience-survive-a-downturn-and-thrive-in-the-next-cycle\"\u003ethe conundrum in the US labor market\u003c/a\u003e: even as the economy cools, there are still nearly twice as many job openings as there are unemployed people. It seems that one of the factors keeping workers on the sidelines is COVID-19. And on the other side of the equation, COVID-19 also seems to be a critical factor holding down productivity and hurting companies\u0026rsquo; ability to keep up with demand.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA billion workdays lost to COVID-19 is enough to have a substantial impact on the economy. Even the midpoint scenario of roughly 600 million workdays lost represents nearly a week missed per worker on average, more than doubling the prepandemic number of sick days taken by Americans.[[footnote 11]] The implied reduction of 1.5 percent in the US labor force is material at a time when unemployment stands at only 3.7 percent, and many sectors are labor constrained.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe impact is asymmetric across industries; those sectors whose workers are unable to be productive remotely bear a greater burden. Exhibit 2 shows our estimates of remote-working potential by sector.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe impact will also likely be disproportionate across regions. Those parts of the country with higher vaccination rates among working-age populations are likely to see less work lost due to severe disease. Areas with economies that are less dependent on industries with a low potential to work remotely will also see a lighter burden.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMoreover, reduced productivity from COVID-19 is likely to continue into this year. Without a change in trajectory, the United States will experience hundreds of millions more COVID-19 cases in 2023, although the situation could improve if milder variants become dominant or if new preventive or therapeutic modalities reduce the average severity of cases or rates of long COVID.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the meantime, workers continue to get sick and miss work. Amid the many ways that COVID-19 has slowed economies, the impact on economic productivity may be among the most enduring.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile this analysis is focused on the United States, many other countries that saw a high number COVID-19 cases during 2022 are also likely to encounter a substantial effect on their workforces. Business and government leaders in these countries may want to take stock of this little-understood economic effect of COVID-19.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":true},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-01-09T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Coronavirus in the US: Latest map and case count,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eNew York Times\u003c/em\u003e, November 23\u0026ndash;December 15, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eData from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) show an average of about 35,000 deaths from influenza per year in the United States from 2010 to 2020, or about 100 per day if deaths were evenly distributed across the year. As immunity wanes, however, the next stage remains highly uncertain. in each of the four categories, we made assumptions based on our work with public-health agencies and a review of the medical literature, always keeping in mind the traditional five-day work week:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAcute illness.\u003c/em\u003e In about two-thirds of COVID-19 cases, symptoms are present. Yet almost all symptomatic cases (98 percent) are considered mild or moderate.[[footnote 1]] Recent estimates suggest that 25 to 30 percent of people infected with COVID-19 isolate for the full recommended period (currently five days) regardless of symptoms.[[footnote 2]] Similarly, about 35 percent of people are considered able to take the time off needed to isolate for any illness, COVID-19 or otherwise.[[footnote 3]] For about 40 percent of the isolators, working from home is not an option, and about five days of work are lost.[[footnote 4]] For those able to work from home, we assume that about 50 percent of their productive capacity is lost, representing some combination of working at half capacity for five days or taking around 2.5 sick days.[[footnote 5]] Taken collectively, this group loses about 0.7 days to 1.0 day of work per case.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eLong COVID.\u003c/em\u003e We conservatively estimate that approximately 5 percent of cases will result in long COVID symptoms that last for 50 days on average.[[footnote 6]] Of those experiencing symptoms, we assume that 88 percent will see a loss of 10 percent of their productivity; the remaining 12 percent will experience wholly debilitating symptoms that preclude work entirely. While there is still much to learn about long COVID, we estimate the contribution of this category at 0.1 to 0.2 days of work per case.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIsolation according to protocol. \u003c/em\u003eAbout one-third of COVID-19 cases are asymptomatic. However, serial and company-mandated testing may capture up to an additional 10 percent of these cases. Assuming that about 30 percent of the population will isolate for the full five days regardless of symptoms,[[footnote 7]] and that about 58 percent of people can work from home,[[footnote 8]] we estimate that isolation protocols cause workers to lose about 0.2 to 0.3 days of work per case.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCaregiving.\u003c/em\u003e For simplicity, we consider the care of only sick children under 12 (about 10 percent of all cases).[[footnote 9]] Recognizing the ability of many parents to work from home or find alternative caregivers, the generally milder course of COVID-19 in children, and the fact that older children will need minimal parental support, we assume that the burden of caregiving leads to 0.1 to 0.2 days of work lost by the caregiving parent, or less than 0.1 days of work lost overall.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Our methodology"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Demographic trends of COVID-19 cases and deaths in the US reported to CDC,\u0026rdquo; US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), accessed on November 17, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCDC estimates 25 to 30 percent of people isolate for the full ten-day period; assumed to extend to a similar range for the five-day period. See \u0026ldquo;What we know about quarantine and isolation,\u0026rdquo; CDC, January 4, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDaniel Schneider of the Harvard Shift Project notes that of those who reported feeling ill at some point during the pandemic, 65 percent worked while they had symptoms. See Olga Khazan, \u0026ldquo;The real reason Americans aren\u0026rsquo;t isolating,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eAtlantic\u003c/em\u003e, January 13, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/real-estate/our-insights/americans-are-embracing-flexible-work-and-they-want-more-of-it\"\u003eAmericans are embracing flexible work\u0026mdash;and want more of it\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; McKinsey, June 23, 2022. Assumes the days of illness are the same as the isolation guidelines.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAssumes that cases of acute COVID-19 result in similar days lost as known for cases of influenza, estimated at less than one to six days per infection. See Martin Keech and Paul Beardsworth, \u0026ldquo;The impact of influenza on working days lost: A review of the literature,\u0026rdquo;\u003cem\u003e PharmacoEconomics\u003c/em\u003e, November 2008, Volume 26, Number 11. We assume near the midpoint of this range at 2.5 days lost per case, or half capacity experienced over five days, recognizing generally milder symptoms experienced with acute COVID-19 infection.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe medical literature is still grappling to understand the frequency, longevity, and severity of long COVID symptoms. Frequency estimations vary: the UK Office of National Statistics estimates about 4 percent as of July 2022 (\u0026ldquo;Self-reported long COVID after infection with the Omicron variant in the UK,\u0026rdquo; Office of National Statistics, July 18, 2022). The CDC estimates 20 percent (Lara Bull-Otterson et al., \u0026ldquo;Post\u0026ndash;COVID conditions among adult COVID-19 survivors aged 18\u0026ndash;64 and \u0026ge;65 Years\u0026mdash;United States, March 2020\u0026ndash;November 2021,\u0026rdquo; CDC, May 27, 2022). Some publications put it at 14 percent (Roy H. Perlis et al., \u0026ldquo;Prevalence and correlates of long COVID symptoms among US adults,\u0026rdquo; JAMA Network, October 27, 2022). Others say 6 percent (Claire E. Hastie et al., \u0026ldquo;Outcomes among confirmed cases and a matched comparison group in the long-COVID in Scotland study,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eNature Communications\u003c/em\u003e, October 12, 2022). We conservatively estimated that 5 percent of cases result in long COVID symptoms. The duration of long COVID is also not yet agreed on and ranges from four to 12 weeks according to several sources including the \u003cem\u003eBMJ\u003c/em\u003e, NHS, and WHO. To strike a balance, we used the halfway point between the four- and 12-week estimates, or 50 days, for average duration. Severity, or the incidence and magnitude of debilitating and mild symptoms, is also not yet agreed on. Publications note debilitating symptoms occurring, such as 15 percent incidence of neurocognitive impairment (\u0026ldquo;What have we learned about long COVID?,\u0026rdquo; Columbia University Irving Medical Center, September 13, 2022), and 8 percent of persons experiencing challenges performing even personal care (\u0026ldquo;Outcomes among confirmed cases,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eNature Communications\u003c/em\u003e, October 12, 2022). We assume that 12 percent of persons experiencing long COVID may experience fully debilitating symptoms for the 50-day duration, whereas our analysis assumes around 88 percent experience only mild debilitation, or around 10 percent productivity loss for the same duration, roughly akin to the on-the-job losses experienced from the common cold (Thomas J. Bramley, Debra Lerner, and Matthew Sames, \u0026ldquo;Productivity losses related to the common cold,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eJournal of Occupational and Environmental Medicine\u003c/em\u003e, 2002, Volume 44, Number 9).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;What we know about quarantine and isolation,\u0026rdquo; CDC, January 4, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca
